examples: The plant grows best in cool climates.
a cool and calculating businessperson
They stayed cool through the emergency.
It's important to keep a cool head =remain calm in a crisis.
a cool impersonal manner
We used to fight, but we're cool now.
a cool reply
got a cool reception
a cool dress
That was a really cool movie.
Is getting together Friday night cool with you?
… not happy with the new shoes … because they were not "cool."
… while over 90% of children think superheroes are “cool,” it was their costume and their ability to save the world they admired most …
Those looking for a cool place to grab a drink with friends will want to check out this list of six special Southern California bars.

data.text: to become cool: lose heat or warmth —sometimes used with off or down
examples: placed the pie in the window to cool
His anger cooled.
cooled the room with a fan
cooled her growing anger
placed the pie in the window to cool

data.text: to make cool: impart a feeling of coolness to —often used with off or down
examples: placed the pie in the window to cool
His anger cooled.
cooled the room with a fan
cooled her growing anger

data.text: a cool time, place, or situation
examples: the cool of the evening
… his ardor, her cool, his earthiness, her spirituality.
The player lost his cool and began yelling at the referee.

data.text: absence of excitement or emotional involvement: detachment
examples: the cool of the evening
… his ardor, her cool, his earthiness, her spirituality.

data.text: in a casual and nonchalant manner
examples: play it cool

data.text: —used like cool to express agreement or approval

examples: The word went out to the young to cool it.

data.text: to wait or be kept waiting for a long time especially from or as if from disdain or discourtesy
